Cranberry Sauce with Orange Zest

Jump to Recipe

Welcome to the ultimate guide for making a delightful Cranberry Sauce with Orange Zest! This vibrant and tangy sauce is a must-have for Thanksgiving feasts, holiday dinners, or any special occasion where you want to impress your guests. Made with fresh cranberries, zesty orange, and just the right amount of sweetness, this recipe elevates a classic side dish into a culinary masterpiece. Not only is this cranberry sauce easy to prepare, but it also brings a burst of flavor that complements turkey, ham, and even breakfast dishes like pancakes. In this article, we will walk you through the simple steps to create this delicious sauce, ensuring you can enjoy a homemade treat that’s both fresh and flavorful. Let’s dive in and discover how to make the best cranberry sauce you’ve ever tasted!

Ingredients

fresh cranberries

Choose bright, firm cranberries for the best flavor and texture. If fresh cranberries are out of season, you can substitute with frozen cranberries; just do not thaw them before cooking. Always rinse them before use to remove any debris.

sugar

Granulated sugar is standard for this recipe, but you can substitute with brown sugar for a deeper flavor, or use honey or maple syrup for a natural sweetener. Adjust the quantity to taste, especially if using sweeter alternatives.

water

Water is used to dissolve the sugar and create the sauce base. You can substitute with orange juice for a richer flavor, or use apple juice for a different fruity twist.

orange zest

Use a microplane or zester to get fine zest without the bitter white pith. If you don't have fresh oranges, you can use store-bought zest or dried orange peel, but use less as it is more concentrated.

orange juice

Freshly squeezed orange juice will provide the best flavor. If unavailable, bottled juice can be used, but ensure it's 100% juice without added sugars. For a twist, consider adding a splash of lemon juice for extra brightness.

Cooking Steps

  • Step 1: Prepare the Cranberries

    Rinse the fresh cranberries under cold water to remove any dirt or impurities. Make sure to pick out any that are soft, shriveled, or damaged—these can affect the texture of your sauce.

  • Step 2: Combine Water and Sugar

    In a medium saucepan, combine 1 cup of water and 1 cup of sugar over medium heat. Stir the mixture gently until the sugar completely dissolves. This step is crucial because it forms the base of your sauce.

  • Step 3: Add Cranberries

    Once the sugar is dissolved, add the rinsed cranberries to the saucepan. Increase the heat to bring the mixture to a boil. This will activate the natural pectin in the cranberries, which helps thicken the sauce.

  • Step 4: Simmer the Sauce

    When the mixture reaches a boil, reduce the heat to low and let it simmer for about 10-12 minutes. During this time, stir occasionally. You'll notice the cranberries will start to burst, releasing their juices, which creates a beautiful sauce.

  • Step 5: Incorporate Orange Zest and Juice

    After the cranberries have burst and the sauce has thickened, stir in 1 tablespoon of orange zest and 1/2 cup of orange juice. This adds a fresh, citrusy flavor that complements the tartness of the cranberries.

  • Step 6: Cool and Serve

    Remove the saucepan from heat and let the sauce cool to room temperature. As it cools, it will continue to thicken. Serve it alongside your favorite dishes, like turkey or ham, or enjoy it as a spread.

Frequently Asked Questions

What should I do if I can't find fresh cranberries?

You can use frozen cranberries instead. Just rinse them under cold water before using them, and you can cook them without thawing.

How do I properly zest an orange?

Use a microplane or a zester to lightly scrape the outer peel of the orange, avoiding the white pith underneath, which can be bitter.

What does it mean to simmer, and how do I do it?

Simmering means cooking at a low heat where small bubbles occasionally rise to the surface. After bringing your mixture to a boil, lower the heat and adjust it so that it bubbles gently.

How can I tell when the cranberries are done cooking?

The cranberries will burst open and the mixture will thicken. This usually takes about 10-12 minutes of simmering.

Can I adjust the sweetness of the cranberry sauce?

Absolutely! Taste the sauce before it's finished and add more sugar if you prefer it sweeter, or reduce the sugar for a tarter flavor.

How should I store leftover cranberry sauce?

Once cooled, store leftover cranberry sauce in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to a week.

What can I serve with cranberry sauce?

Cranberry sauce pairs wonderfully with turkey, ham, or even as a topping for desserts like cheesecake or yogurt.

Is it safe to eat raw cranberries?

Yes, raw cranberries are safe to eat, but they are very tart. Cooking them makes them sweeter and more palatable.

What kitchen tools do I need for this recipe?

You'll need a medium saucepan, a wooden spoon for stirring, and a zester or microplane for the orange zest. A measuring cup and spoon are also necessary.

Can I make this sauce ahead of time?

Yes! Cranberry sauce can be made up to a week in advance, and the flavors often improve after sitting for a day or two.

Additional Information

Dietary Considerations

This cranberry sauce is naturally vegetarian and gluten-free. For a lower sugar version, you can substitute half of the sugar with a sugar alternative like agave syrup or maple syrup. Additionally, for those watching their sugar intake, consider using unsweetened cranberry juice in place of the water and sugar, though this may alter the texture slightly.

Pairings

Cranberry Sauce with Orange Zest pairs beautifully with roasted turkey, pork loin, or a savory duck dish. For a vegetarian option, serve it alongside a nut and cheese platter or as a condiment for a savory tart. As for beverages, consider a crisp white wine like Sauvignon Blanc or a light-bodied red like Pinot Noir, which complement the tartness of the cranberries. For something non-alcoholic, a sparkling water with a hint of citrus would be refreshing.

Serving Suggestions

Serve the cranberry sauce in a decorative bowl at room temperature to highlight its vibrant color. Consider garnishing with a few whole cranberries and a sprinkle of orange zest on top for an elegant touch. This sauce can also be served in small jars as part of a homemade gift for the holidays. For a more casual setting, drizzle it over crostini topped with cream cheese or goat cheese for an appealing appetizer.

Cranberry Sauce with Orange Zest

25 min
$3.5
110 kcal
Difficulty: 10%
Servings: 8

Dietary Tags:

VegetarianVeganGluten-Free

Cuisine:

American

Course:

Side Dish

Tags:

EasyQuickHolidaySide Dish

Description

A vibrant and refreshing cranberry sauce with a hint of zesty orange, perfect for holiday meals!

Ingredients

  • fresh cranberries: 12 oz
  • sugar: 1 cup
  • water: 1 cup
  • orange zest: 1 tbsp
  • orange juice: 1/2 cup
